RealEstateAnalysis (ComparativeMarketAna.yes_scenario: Despite affordability strains and government cooling attempts, price growth in Madrid re-accelerates in late 2025 as international capital (fleeing weaker European cities, chasing real returns) targets Madrid, and rent surges force buyers off the fence. RealEstateAnalysis (ComparativeMarketAna.final_reasoning: Madrid's 2024 performance (+20%) sets a high bar. All available comparative and fundamental analysis—grounded in CMAs and leveraged forecasts—puts 2025 expectation at strong, but moderating, nominal growth. Recent data (Q2: +14% YoY) shows deceleration, not re-acceleration. The supply shortage remains severe and investor demand is strong, but rapid price appreciation faces mounting headwinds: severe affordability squeeze (youth/families sidelined), government alarms (targeting demand/funds), and already-pervasive bubble warnings (UBS, others). Historical base rates for two consecutive 18%+ years in a developed, regulated city are extremely low even with structural shortages—the kind of double-digit expansion that continues without pause is rare. While a disorderly international inflow or regulatory misstep could deliver a shock, the most likely outcome—grounded in market analytics, status quo inertia, and available forecasts—is substantial growth but under the 18% resolving bar. That said, the persistent supply-demand crunch and unique capital flows justify modestly non-zero tails. On balance, as of late September 2025, I assign a probability of 17% to a >18% nominal rise in Madrid housing from December 2024 to December 2025.

RealEstateAnalysis (HedonicPricingModel).no_scenario: Supply remains constrained, but macroeconomic stability, rising unaffordability, and minor demand fatigue combine to slow price appreciation to 9–14% YoY in Madrid. Market activity remains brisk, but enough buyers get priced out that gains moderate.

Domestic institutional or retail investors/speculators, expecting continued appreciation, accelerate purchases; supply shortages worsen, and there is a 'blowoff top' dynamic where price growth re-accelerates from already elevated 2025 levels to 18%+ YoY by December. Possible exacerbating factors include currency inflows, policy missteps fueling FOMO, or a major new inflow of high-net-worth buyers.
RealEstateAnalysis (HedonicPricingModel).final_reasoning: Despite profound undersupply and continuing foreign interest, most current data point to a slight moderation in Madrid price growth. The fundamental drivers (supply constraint, foreign demand, urban desirability) are extraordinarily strong, but affordability has hit limits, especially for the local population, and primary market players now expect annual price gains to slow to the 8-13% range in 2025 (from 20% the previous year). While boom/bubble dynamics and positive momentum could produce one more outsized year, double-digit base effects and the rarity of back-to-back 18%+ years in advanced markets make such an outcome unlikely. No major forecaster sees this outcome as baseline. Though an upside surprise is possible, the status quo, consensus, and macro context point strongly against >18% growth. I estimate the probability of >18% price growth in Madrid in 2025 to be low, but not zero: roughly 8%.

Affordability ceilings, souring sentiment about overvaluation, the end of the golden visa, and increased warning signals from both analysts and policymakers are likely to moderate further acceleration, not to mention the 'mean reversion' that typically follows an anomalously high leap. Nicking into the 12–15% range is highly plausible. Surpassing 18% would require additional exogenous shocks (financial repression, abrupt migration wave, or delayed reporting of market cooling). Therefore, the probability of >18% growth is much lower than a superficial trend following would suggest, despite very strong fundamentals and the ongoing expansion phase.
